data.title: Why Are Stock Market Futures Down Today, 2/26/26?
data.description:
U.S. stock futures moved lower Thursday night as investors reacted to weakness in Nvidia (NVDA) and waited for a key inflation report due Friday morning. Futures on the Nasdaq 100 (NDX), the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA), and the S&P 500 (SPX) Index were down by 0.38%, 0.56%, and 0.43%, respectively, at 8:01 p.m. EDT on February 26.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The pressure came after the S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Nasdaq dropped 1.2% during Thursday's regular trading session, while the Dow managed a small gain. Nvidia stock was the biggest surprise of the day, sliding 5.5% despite strong quarterly results.

In extended trading, notable software names moved lower. Salesforce (CRM) fell more than 2% and Microsoft (MSFT) slipped about 1%, weighing on Dow futures. Cybersecurity firm Zscaler (ZS) dropped nearly 10% after fiscal Q2 deferred revenue and billings missed estimates. CoreWeave (CRWV) slid about 9% on weak guidance.

All eyes now turn to January's Producer Price Index (PPI), a key measure of wholesale inflation. Economists expect both headline and core PPI to rise 0.3%. The report could influence expectations for the Federal Reserve's next steps.
data.author: Shalu Saraf

data.title: Intel Stock (NASDAQ:INTC) Plunges After Key Figure Loss
data.description:
Bad news hit chip stock Intel (INTC), as one of its biggest names in the foundry operation has departed the company for a job at Qualcomm (QCOM) instead. Kevin O'Buckley, former senior vice president and general manager of Intel Foundry Services, is now Qualcomm's vice president of global operations and supply chain. This news hit investors like a bus, and Intel shares bled out nearly 3.5% of their value in Thursday afternoon's trading.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Intel, perhaps as a kind of damage control, noted that Intel Foundry remains "…one of Intel's highest strategic priorities." Further, Intel looks for Intel Foundry to remain "…focused on disciplined execution and delivering for customers" under the new leadership of Naga Chandrasekaran, who took over the top slot therein last year.

Meanwhile, Intel thanked O'Buckley for his service, wishing him "the very best" as he took on his new role. Why O'Buckley left is not immediately clear. Some note that O'Buckley formerly reported to Lip-Bu Tan himself, but with the changes to Intel Foundry, would report to Chandrasekaran instead. The idea of no longer having access to the top might have rankled O'Buckley, but that is strictly speculative.

A New Battle With Nvidia

While it would be safe to say that Nvidia (NVDA) has a vested interest in Intel's success—especially given the $5 billion investment it made in Intel back in December—it also has a vested interest in beating Intel. Nvidia is out to branch out into the CPU market, a decidedly different market from the GPU that it commonly handles.

CPUs are making a comeback, reports note, with artificial intelligence (AI) companies moving from training models to deploying them instead. That typically calls for CPU power, and Nvidia wants to be in the thick of that market, offering up its own breed of CPU to take advantage of the "dance with the one who brought you" market.

Is Intel a Buy, Hold or Sell?

Turning to Wall Street, analysts have a Hold consensus rating on INTC stock based on eight Buys, 21 Holds and four Sells assigned in the past three months, as indicated by the graphic below. After a 103.03% rally in its share price over the past year, the average INTC price target of $48.21 per share implies 6.67% upside potential.
data.author: Steve Anderson

data.title: AI Software or AI Chips? Investors Weigh These Two ETFs after Nvidia Earnings
data.description:
After Nvidia (NVDA) reported better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter results, investors are looking for ways to stay exposed to artificial intelligence without choosing individual stocks. BlackRock's (BLK) iShares lineup offers two ways to invest in AI: chipmakers that power the technology, represented by the iShares Semiconductor ETF (SOXX), and software companies that build applications using it, represented by the iShares Expanded Tech-Software ETF (IGV). Using the TipRanks ETF Comparison Tool, we compared the two ETFs across holdings, performance, and analyst outlook.

data.title: CrowdStrike Stock (CRWD): JPMorgan, D.A. Davidson Stay Bullish Ahead of Q4 Earnings, But Lower Price Targets
data.description:
Cybersecurity company CrowdStrike Holdings (CRWD) is scheduled to announce results for the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2026 on March 3. CRWD stock has declined 19% year-to-date amid concerns about artificial intelligence (AI) disrupting the cybersecurity sector, as AI startup Anthropic added a new security tool to its Claude model. Nonetheless, JPMorgan and D.A. Davidson reiterated Buy ratings on CrowdStrike stock but lowered their price targets. Let's discuss their views on the cybersecurity stock.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Interestingly, CrowdStrike stock rose 4.9% on Thursday after Nvidia (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang dismissed fears that AI agents would cannibalize the enterprise software industry.

Wall Street expects CrowdStrike to report earnings per share (EPS) of $1.10 for Q4 FY26, reflecting about 7% year-over-year growth. Revenue is projected to rise 22.6% to $1.30 billion.
data.author: Sirisha Bhogaraju

data.title: U.S. Stock Futures Dip ahead of Key Inflation Report
data.description:
U.S. stock futures slipped Thursday evening as the market braced for a key inflation report due tomorrow morning. Futures on the Nasdaq 100 (NDX), the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA), and the S&P 500 Index (SPX) were down 0.3%, 0.52%, and 0.35%, respectively, at 6:42 p.m. EST on February 26.

The pressure came after the S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Nasdaq dropped 1.2% during Thursday's regular trading session, while the Dow managed a small gain. Nvidia stock (NVDA) was the biggest surprise of the day, sliding 5.5% despite strong quarterly results.

All eyes now turn to January's Producer Price Index (PPI), a key measure of wholesale inflation. Economists expect both headline and core PPI to rise 0.3%. The report could influence expectations for the Federal Reserve's next steps.

data.title: Stock Market Today: SPY, QQQ Dragged Down by Nvidia amid 'Positive' U.S.-Iran Talks
data.description:
The S&P 500 ETF (SPY) and the Nasdaq 100 ETF (QQQ) closed lower on Thursday, although both ETFs staged partial recoveries from their intraday lows.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Despite a double beat on both revenue and earnings, Nvidia (NVDA) ended the day with a 5.49% loss. NVDA is the largest holding in both SPY and QQQ with weights of 7.83% and 8.90%, respectively.

  • Revenue: $68.13 billion vs. $66.21 billion estimated
  • Data center revenue: $62.3 billion vs. $60.69 billion estimated
  • Adjusted EPS: $1.62 vs. $1.53 estimated
  • Fiscal First-Quarter Guidance: $78 billion plus or minus 2% vs est. $72.6 billion

The semiconductor leader's results weren't enough to ward off fears of an AI bubble, high customer concentration, and the sustainability of investments in AI. In addition, investors zoned in on Nvidia's purchase commitments, which rose by 90.2% quarter-over-quarter to $95.2 billion.

"The debate has shifted away from near-term results and toward the sustainability of AI capex spending, amid concerns around its quantum, monetization and potential cashflow degradation," said Janus Henderson portfolio manager Richard Clode.

Meanwhile, the U.S. and Iran held indirect nuclear talks in Geneva, with a senior U.S. official describing them as "positive." Omani Foreign Minister Badr al-Busaidi added that the two sides made "significant progress," with technical talks scheduled in Vienna next week. At the same time, key disagreements remain, with the U.S. calling on Iran to eliminate its 10,000-kilogram stockpile of enriched uranium. Iran rejected this proposal and pushed for low enrichment levels monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

Before the market opened, the Department of Labor announced that initial jobless claims for the week ended February 21 rose by 4,000 to 212,000, below the consensus estimate of 216,000. Continuing jobless claims, which trail initial claims by a week, fell by 31,000 to 1.833 million and undershot expectations of 1.858 million. Initial jobless claims track new layoffs, while continuing claims reflect the level of ongoing unemployment.

Finally, the Trump administration is weighing its options to retain tariff revenue collected under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), according to Politico. Several options are on the table, including a proposal that contends tariffs collected over the past year comply with a new set of duties the administration is now implementing under different legal frameworks. Another option would allow companies to move to the front of the refund line by agreeing to forfeit part of the money to the government. Thousands of companies have already filed lawsuits seeking refunds, including Costco (COST) and FedEx (FDX).

The S&P 500 (SPX) closed with a 0.54% loss, while the Nasdaq 100 (NDX) fell by 1.16%.
data.author: Eddie Pan

data.title: Netflix Stock (NFLX) Jumps after Streaming Giant Walks Away from Warner Bros. (WBD) Deal
data.description:
Streaming giant Netflix (NFLX) has decided to walk away from its bid for Warner Bros. (WBD), marking a dramatic turn in one of Hollywood's most closely watched takeover battles. Following the news, NFLX stock rose about 10% in the after-hours trading.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

This move came after Warner Bros.' board determined that Paramount Skydance's (PSKY) latest offer qualified as a "Superior Proposal." Netflix confirmed it would not raise its bid, effectively ending its pursuit of the merger.

Co‑CEOs Ted Sarandos and Greg Peters said the company remained disciplined throughout negotiations and concluded that matching Paramount Skydance's higher price "is no longer financially attractive."

Instead of escalating the bidding war, Netflix is turning its focus back to its core business. The company highlighted its strong organic growth, plans to invest roughly $20 billion this year in films and series, and its intention to resume share buybacks under its capital allocation strategy.

The move clears the way for Paramount Skydance, whose higher all-cash bid and willingness to cover breakup fees shifted the deal landscape.

Is Netflix a Good Stock to Buy Now?

Turning to Wall Street, NFLX stock has a Moderate Buy consensus rating based on 27 Buys, nine Holds, and one Sell assigned in the last three months. At $113.88, the average Netflix stock price target implies a 34.63% upside potential.
data.author: Radhika Saraogi

data.title: 'As Expected,' Top Analysts Praise Nvidia's Stellar Q4 Results
data.description:
Chip giant Nvidia (NVDA) delivered another solid quarterly performance, beating sales and earnings estimates amid rising AI demand from hyperscalers. TipRanks' five-star analysts expected Nvidia to surpass expectations, driven by high double-digit data center sales growth. TD Cowen analyst Joshua Buchalter reiterated his Buy rating and $235 price target, implying 20.2% upside potential. Similarly, Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh maintained his Buy rating and $275 price target, suggesting 40.6% upside.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Nvidia Remains TD Cowen's Top Pick

Buchalter named Nvidia his "Top Pick," noting it makes "the extraordinary seem ordinary." The top four hyperscalers are expected to spend $650-$700 billion on capex this year, signaling "all systems go" at NVIDIA.

Buchalter expects growth through 2026, with revenue from Blackwell and Rubin platforms likely surpassing the $500 billion target. He noted that despite solid fundamentals, NVDA stock trades at a discount to historical valuations and peers, with investor skepticism on AI sustainability.

Rakesh Highlights Future Potential

Rakesh highlighted that Nvidia guided Q1FY26 revenue of $78 billion (+/- 2%), well above the $72.6 billion consensus, fueled by strong Blackwell ramps despite zero China revenue. He added that Rubin samples are now with customers and are on track for H2 2026 launch, targeting 10x inference cost reduction versus Blackwell.

Blackwell ramps continue strongly into H1 2026, with Rubin driving H2 and total demand exceeding $500 billion from inference and sovereign AI. He forecasts AI infrastructure market hitting $3 to $4 trillion by 2030, with agentic/physical AI and software-as-a-token driving growth.

Is NVDA a Good Stock to Buy Now?

On TipRanks, Nvidia stock commands a Strong Buy consensus rating based on 34 Buys and one Sell rating. The average Nvidia price target of $267.48 implies 36.8% upside potential from current levels. Over the past year, NVDA shares have surged 49%.
data.author: Sheryl Sheth

data.title: WBD Says Paramount's (PSKY) Offer is "Superior," Triggering a Four-Day Countdown for Netflix (NFLX)
data.description:
Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) has taken a major step in its high‑stakes takeover battle. It said its Board of Directors has formally determined that Paramount Skydance's (PSKY) latest bid qualifies as a "Company Superior Proposal" when compared with its existing merger agreement with Netflix (NFLX). This move formally triggers a four-business-day matching period for Netflix to improve its bid.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Paramount Skydance's Bid Clears the Bar

WBD's board, after consulting its independent advisors, decided that Paramount Skydance's offer, valued at about $111 billion, provides more value and protection than the $83 billion deal currently on the table with Netflix.

The deal includes:

  • Purchase Price: $31.00 per WBD share in cash, up from a previous $30.00 offer.
  • Ticking Fee: A fee of $0.25 per share per quarter, beginning after September 30, 2026, to protect shareholders against closing delays.
  • Termination Protections: The deal includes a $7 billion regulatory termination fee if the deal fails to clear antitrust hurdles and a commitment to pay the $2.8 billion breakup fee WBD would owe Netflix.
  • Financial Backing: Larry J. Ellison and associated trusts have committed additional equity funding to ensure the solvency requirements of lending banks are met.
  • Asset Scope: Unlike Netflix, which primarily sought WBD's studios and HBO assets, Paramount Skydance intends to acquire the entire company, including its linear TV networks like CNN and Discovery.

NFLX Has Four Business Days to Respond

WBD has formally notified Netflix of its decision. Under the merger agreement, this notice opens a four‑business‑day matching window. During this period, Netflix can raise its bid or change deal terms to match or beat Paramount's proposal.

Once this period ends, WBD's board will review both proposals again. If, after reviewing any revisions from Netflix, the board still believes Paramount's bid is superior, WBD can end its merger agreement with Netflix and proceed with PSKY.

All attention now shifts to how Netflix will respond. The company must decide whether to improve its offer, hold its ground, or walk away. Meanwhile, WBD's board will continue to evaluate its future path with its advisors.

Which Stock Is a Better Buy?

We used TipRanks' Comparison Tool to line up all three companies in the takeover battle, to see which ones analysts favor. Below is a screenshot for reference. According to analysts, Netflix stock has the highest upside potential of 34.63%.
data.author: Radhika Saraogi
